issue.title: the platform of getsentry/rust-musl-cross images on docker hub is amd64 regardless of tagged platform
issue.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180551/204577371-2f04623c-d6f0-4cd9-9ac6-b3d5f4be6e72.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

tried to `docker build -t .` on an aarch64 platform.

### Expected Result

successful build of docker image

### Actual Result

```
[centos@ip-172-31-3-238 sentry-cli]$ docker build --no-cache --platform linux/arm64/v8 --build-arg BUILD_ARCH=aarch64 -t sentry-cli .
Sending build context to Docker daemon  748.5kB
Step 1/18 : ARG BUILD_ARCH=aarch64
Step 2/18 : ARG BUILD_LIBC=musl
Step 3/18 : FROM getsentry/rust-musl-cross:$BUILD_ARCH-$BUILD_LIBC AS sentry-build
 ---> beec240083fe
Step 4/18 : ARG BUILD_ARCH
 ---> [Warning] The requested image's platform (linux/amd64) does not match the detected host platform (linux/arm64/v8) and no specific platform was requested
 ---> Running in 4a8624f7d08e
...
standard_init_linux.go:228: exec user process caused: exec format error
```

comment.body:
My point is that it is not possible to build a sentry-cli binary with the given docker file.
When I change the `FROM getsentry/rust-musl-cross` to `FROM messense/rust-musl-cross` things work properly.

### Steps to Reproduce

### Expected Result

successful build of docker image

### Actual Result

```
[centos@ip-172-31-3-238 sentry-cli]$ docker build --no-cache --platform linux/arm64/v8 --build-arg BUILD_ARCH=aarch64 -t sentry-cli .
Sending build context to Docker daemon  748.5kB
Step 1/18 : ARG BUILD_ARCH=aarch64
Step 2/18 : ARG BUILD_LIBC=musl
Step 3/18 : FROM getsentry/rust-musl-cross:$BUILD_ARCH-$BUILD_LIBC AS sentry-build
 ---> beec240083fe
Step 4/18 : ARG BUILD_ARCH
 ---> [Warning] The requested image's platform (linux/amd64) does not match the detected host platform (linux/arm64/v8) and no specific platform was requested
 ---> Running in 4a8624f7d08e
...
standard_init_linux.go:228: exec user process caused: exec format error
```

issue.title: Add tag support to the bash-hook send event command
issue.body:
Hey!

I'm using sentry-cli to track issues in my deployment scripts ran on the AWS Amplify Console. I have a `.yml` file where I setup Sentry CLI and run the `eval "$(sentry-cli bash-hook --cli 'sentry-cli ...')"` command to setup sentry in the runner. 

It works fine, but I want to add extra data to the errors and I tought I could use [Sentry Tags](https://docs.sentry.io/product/cli/send-event/#extra-data) using the `-t` parameter, but I found that there's no way I can send parameters to the bash-hook command, located in the `src/bashsupport.sh` script.

I tried to add this feature request by my own, I forked the repo but to be honest I don't have any experience in Rust for building packages. So I will appreciate if somebody could add this simple but important feature.

comment.body: Hey, we're also looking for this feature! please merge #1398

comment.diff_hunk:

             self.vms_session.patch("views/{}".format(export.id), data=dict(policy_id=policy.id))

issue.title: why can't we catch/suppress ConditionalCheckFailedException?
issue.body:
It seems quite unpythonic to force users to write such constructs when dealing with the oh-so-useful conditional operations in DynamoDM:

```python
try:
    thread_item.save(Thread.forum_name.exists())
except PutError as e:
    if isinstance(e.cause, ClientError):
        code = e.cause.response['Error'].get('Code')
        print(code == "ConditionalCheckFailedException")
```

PynamoDB already issues it own exceptions - why not perform this `if` and raise a `ConditionalCheckFailed`? why perpetuate the bad API for boto3 (in this regard) into this otherwise very pythonic library?

Make this work:
```python
try:
    thread_item.save(Thread.forum_name.exists())
except ConditionalCheckFailed:
    pass

```

commits.message: logging: bug fix on ThreadControl use of logging.LogRecord
concurrency: Futures.execution() logs when futures are hanging
concurrency: cleaner thread naming scheme for concurrent/Future
